Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education (Mr. Allen)
Speaker.P: At the outset, I should first explain that overall responsibility for the operation and administration of a vocational education committee school rests with the vocational education committee concerned, and the responsible body is Bray vocational education committee.

MainHeading.P: Complaints concerning the school in question first came to the attention of my Department in November 1995 when senior officials of the Department met with the parents' representative on the committee. The representative was advised that responsibility for the operation of the school and its day-to-day management rested with the vocational education committee and the board of management of the school, but if written information was provided on specific incidents of complaint, the matter would be taken up with the vocational education committee. However, no written material was provided.

In March 1996 the Minister received a letter signed by a number of parents and two former teachers at the school requesting a meeting with the Minister and requesting that certain matters be investigated. The Minister also received representations from Senator Roche on behalf of two of the parents. It was clear from the letters that the issues had already been raised by the parents with the vocational education committee and had been considered by the vocational education committee on a number of occasions. The complaints related to the treatment of children and their parents by an employee of the vocational education committee, the non-payment of a book grant to a child and the general ethos and atmosphere of the school.

In response to the representations from Senator Roche, the vocational education committee was requested to investigate the matters raised by him. The vocational education committee responded to the effect that the issue raised had been considered in great detail by the school's board of management and by Bray vocational education committee. Following consideration of the reply, a further letter was sent to the vocational education committee on 26 April seeking further clarification. In that letter the case made by the parents and the former teachers was also referred to and copies of the letters which had been received were sent to the vocational education committee for their consideration. The vocational education committee was requested to report to the Department as soon as possible.

The procedure for dealing with cases in which complaints are made against a vocational education committee teacher is that the employer of the teacher is made aware of the allegations, and in this case Bray vocational education committee is the employer. Where specific allegations are made regarding an employee of a vocational education committee, the vocational education committee, as the employer, has a duty of care to the children in its care and must have these allegations investigated. It is incumbent on the Minister to make the allegations known to the vocational education committee to enable it to discharge its responsibility. Where the complainants indicate that they do not want their identity known outside the Department, this wish is normally acceded to. Nothing in any of the letters received by the Department in this case indicated that the authors wished to remain anonymous.

The chief executive officer has advised the Department by letter of 21 May that the matter was again considered at a special meeting of Bray vocational education committee on 19 May. My Department is currently examining the committee's response and shall be responding to Senator Roche and the parents in due course.

The Minister is very much aware of the concerns of each of the parents involved. Department officials continue to be available to the parents to assist in the resolution of this issue. However, the Minister is satisfied that proper procedures were followed by the Department in dealing with this matter. I will bring the points raised by Senator Roche to the attention of the Minister.

Speaker.P: I do not disagree with any of the facts as presented by the Minister except that I do not believe or accept, and any impartial judgment would accord with my view, that Bray vocational education committee has handled this matter properly. Bray vocational education committee has handled this matter in an extraordinarily dismissive manner. That is why I have taken the extraordinary step of asking that an inspector be asked to examine the matter in Bray.

MainHeading.P: People's complaints, which may be individually small, were treated in a dismissive, offhanded and, in my view, unacceptable way. I know the Minister is as concerned about client service as I am. I am concerned about my constituents and I defend their interests in the same way as the Minister defends his constituents' interests. I ask the Minister to insist that an inspector examine these matters. I thank the Minister for his time and attention.
